text:
The article goes on to say that I went to Gulenist schools and met these military officers there. That is also not true.

As for the article's claim that I learned to speak Turkish in Gulenist schools - I don't speak Turkish, as anyone who has listened to me try can attest.
author: DavidKenner

text:
According to a Turkish newspaper, an indictment of several Turkish officers says I reported them as Gulenists. 

None of this is true. I have no idea who these people are, and never reported on anybody. Nobody should be convicted on ‘evidence’ like this.

text:
First and foremost: 

-Who is going to man this 20-mile safe zone, presumably between Turkey and Syria? 

-US-Turkey trade totals around $16b/year; Turkey's GDP is ~$850b. Can US really "economically devastate" Turkey? In what universe do sanctions make Ankara more cooperative?

text:
Final point on this for now: For ~6 years, Israel and Hezbollah fought in Syria even as both had no interest in the conflict spilling over into Lebanon. 

The IDF op is a sign that this arrangement is unsustainable. Syrian and Lebanese fronts can't be kept separate forever.
author: DavidKenner

text:
IDF spox: "The neutralizing of the tunnels will not necessarily take place within our territory." 

Needless to say, ops in Lebanese territory would change this situation dramatically.
author: DavidKenner

text: Israel has been quietly developing tech to detect tunnels for the past decade-plus -- it's the increasing accuracy of Hezbollah's missiles that could really change the balance of power on the Israel-Lebanon border. https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2018/07/hezbollah-iran-new-weapons-israel/565796/ …

text: There aren’t any easy answers here. De Mistura doesn’t sit at the head of an army – he can’t force anyone to make peace. At the same time, there’s no denying that he presided over the increasing irrelevance of the UN to events in Syria. 6/6
author: DavidKenner

text: Other diplomats favored option #2. De Mistura’s approach, they told me, was a recipe for complacency and self-censorship. If De Mistura had resigned years ago, they said, he could have pushed the Security Council to admit that its diplomatic process was fundamentally broken. 5/6
author: DavidKenner

text: De Mistura agreed. One of his former aides told me, “[His] philosophy was: The UN should not give up hope. Even if Security Council members play games, we should believe their games. He knew…these paths will not get anyone anywhere, but it was the only game in town.” 4/6
author: DavidKenner

text: Those who praised de Mistura’s perseverance and long tenure favored option #1. Doing anything that caused Assad’s government to cut off access or making a dramatic resignation wasn’t going to save a single life, they argued to me, and would only make restarting talks harder. 3/6
author: DavidKenner

text: The question is: Is their purpose to convene the great powers and help them reach an agreement that ratified the military reality? Or can the UN lead the way, proposing its own solutions and shaming parties that fail to live up to its standards? 2/6
author: DavidKenner

text: If you’re interested in Syria and/or the hard work of diplomacy, read my profile of UN special envoy Staffan de Mistura. One point to add: His staff would sometimes debate a basic question about their role in the conflict. 1/6
author: DavidKenner

text: As Staffan de Mistura prepares to step down as UN special envoy for Syria, I profile why he failed - and why former members of his team describe his efforts as a Syrian version of the Israeli-Palestinian “peace process.” https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2018/11/un-syria-envoy-staffan-de-mistura/576550/ …

text: For that reason, among others, most people I interviewed didn't expect Assad to reconquer it in one fell swoop. The Turkey-Russia deal contains the potential for an incremental approach - if HTS doesn't withdraw from the buffer zone, Putin could use it to justify an attack there.

text: Thank you so much to @sbg1, @blakehounshell, at @benpauker and innumerable others for empowering me. It's not everyone that would have let a 20-something kid report from Libya during an uprising, move to Egypt to cover a revolution, or go to Gaza and Iraq to cover wars.
author: DavidKenner

text: What a long, strange, frenzied, sometimes exasperating, always amazing journey it has been. It has been a privilege to be a part of FP as it grew - publishing articles from across the globe, responding to breaking news, bringing in new voices to the debate.
author: DavidKenner

text: You could count the members of our editorial team on both hands (one hand, some days). Publishing two or three articles in a day was considered a deluge of content - almost entirely think pieces written by Washington-based analysts.
author: DavidKenner

text: All good things, as they say, must come to an end. On a related note: Today is my last day at @ForeignPolicy! I just wanted to take a brief moment to note how far we've come. When I joined FP in 2009, our website looked like this.
author: DavidKenner

text: Anti-ISIS coalition reporting that two service members were killed and five wounded by an IED in northern Syria. The timing lines up with reports of an IED explosion in Manbij last night.
author: DavidKenner

text: I spoke with @PMaurerICRC about the humanitarian disaster in Eastern Ghouta, and the struggles aid organizations face in Syria.
